text:
[s=24]kernel[/s]
A central software that manages [s=24]👨🏻‍💼[/s] 
and allocates computer resources 
(i.e., the CPU, RAM, and devices).

accompanying standard software tools,
such as 
browsers 🌍
command-line interpreters 📟
graphical user interfaces 📱
file utilities📄
editors

The Linux kernel executable typically resides at the pathname 

   [s=24]🪑/boot/vmlinuz[/s]

CPU MODES - [s=24]🖥️[/s]

Kernel mode and user mode

Kernel mode or supervisor mode
[s=24]💪[/s]

User mode
[s=24]🚫[/s]
Can access what is allowed

What is the use of being a [s=24]process 😩[/s]

When will i get scheduled
Where am i in RAM
How can i talk to my friends
When will i get the signals
When will i get the CPU time
I cannot even talk to devices directly
I cannot even create my own child process

Only [s=32]KERNEL[/s] knows

[s=32]🐚SHELL🌊[/s]

login shell denotes a process created to run a shell when the user first logs in .

Bourne shell (sh) 👶 - Oldest and widely used

C shell (csh) - Not so portable. no backward compatible

Korn shell (ksh) 🌽 - backward compatible

Bourne again shell (bash) 👶 🔁-reimplementation of the Bourne shell. Most widely used shell in linux

Every user [s=24]🙍🏻‍♂️[/s] has a unique user name and UID 
it is in [s=24]/etc/passwd[/s]

This file also has
Group ID 👨‍👨‍👦‍👦: the numeric group ID of the [s=24]first[/s] of the groups of which the user is a
member.

Home [s=24]🏠[/s] directory: the initial directory into which the user is placed after logging in.

Login [s=24]🔐[/s] shell: the name of the program to be executed to interpret user commands

[s=24]superuser 💪[/s]

user ID 0
typical login name root. [s=24]🪵[/s]

superuser can access any file in the system
send signals to any user process in the system
so on and so forth

[s=24]groups 👨‍👨‍👦‍👦[/s]

Each group is identified by a single line in the system group file, [s=32]/etc/group[/s]

Group name: unique name of the group.

Group ID (GID): the numeric ID

User list: comma separated line of users. Primary group listed in [s=24]/etc/passwd[/s]
